fr:title.text: With Leoni Pugh: When is the partial map classifier a Sierpi≈Ñski cone?

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: With Leoni Pugh: When is the partial map classifier a Sierpi≈Ñski cone?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Leoni Pugh is my old Part III student from 2023‚Äì2024, and this work builds on her Part III dissertation. The goal of our paper was to better understand the relationship between two approaches to partial functions in denotational semantics:

html:ol.html:li: ‚ÄúGeometrical‚Äù partiality / ‚Äúthe Sierpi≈Ñski cone‚Äù: freely add a lowest element to the space representing a given data type. This is useful for defining functions whose inputs are partially defined, because you can do a case-analysis on the definedness of the input.

‚ÄúLogical‚Äù partiality / ‚Äúthe partial map classifier‚Äù: representing partially defined elements of a space X by pairs
( p,x )
where p is a proposition and x is a function from isTrue
( p )
to X. This is useful for defining functions whose outputs are partially defined.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In traditional domain theory as developed by Scott, the two kinds of partiality coincide‚Äîeven constructively. I am, however, interested in synthetic domain theory which abstracts away from continuity and limits and lets you just use sets and functions rather than cpos and continuous functions‚Äîprovided that you avoid non-constructive principles like the Axiom of Choice or the Law of Excluded Middle. The starting point of our work is my observation that the two notions cannot coincide absolutely in synthetic domain theory, but that there may be restricted subuniverses in which they do coincide. The main result of our paper is to define such a subuniverse, made possible by my discovery of the based Segal condition‚Äîa strengthening of the usual Segal condition for higher categories.

A broader motivation of this work is to develop synthetic domain theory and synthetic higher category theory within the same framework. Whereas synthetic domain theory traditionally concerned itself with spaces that behaved like œâ-complete partial orders (but where all functions are automatically monotone and continuous), the same ideas (if applied within homotopy type theory) allow you to consider spaces that behave like ‚àû-categories with colimits of œâ-chains (but where all functions are automatically ‚àû-functorial and œâ-continuous). I believe that unifying domain theory and higher category theory will prove useful for studying things like the denotational semantics of concurrency, which is inherently higher-dimensional.

fr:title.text: With Andrew Slattery: Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting of fibred categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: With Andrew Slattery: Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting of fibred categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This year, Thomas Streicher (born 1958) passed away from cancer. Thomas was one of the Greats of dependent type theory and he also wrote an excellent textbook on domain theory for denotational semantics, but much more importantly he was kind and curious and patient and always made time for young people. While I was still finding my place in the community, Thomas was very generous to me with his time and advice, and he sent me many papers to referee.

Although Thomas made many contributions to dependent type theory, domain theory, realisability theory, and category theory, he is most known to type theorists for two things‚Äîboth in collaboration with the late Martin Hofmann: the groupoid interpretation of type theory and the eponymous Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher universe lifting construction. Andrew and my paper pertains to the latter.

The idea of Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting has to do with universes, which are ‚Äútypes of types‚Äù (typically defined in such a way as to avoid paradoxes). Martin-L√∂f type theory usually includes universes in order to be able to quantify over (small enough) types; in the simplest models of Martin-L√∂f type theory, types are interpreted as sets and so Martin-L√∂f‚Äôs universes are interpreted as certain sets of sets, such as Grothendieck universes. But it is important to be able to interpret the language of type theory in more sophisticated worlds than set theory: for example, in presheaves (which are functors from a fixed category C into Set). What Hofmann and Streicher did is show how to transform any universe of sets into a universe of presheaves!

Although Hofmann and Streicher‚Äôs construction worked well and had good properties, they did not find a universal property for it‚Äîwhich is an abstract description of the object that determines it uniquely up to isomorphism, usually in terms of how it relates to other objects. Recently Awodey found a 1-dimensional universal property, which was the starting point of our work. What Andrew and I wanted to do is generalise Awodey‚Äôs analysis in two directions:

html:ol.html:li: We wanted a 2-dimensional version, which is useful because it captures more about the universe than can be said in just one dimension: for example, with a 2-dimensional version, you can see immediately (by ‚Äúabstract nonsense‚Äù) that Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting preserves structures like monads, adjunctions, etc. that might be used for modelling computational effects, etc.

We wanted a relative version, which would make it easier to iterate the Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting construction: the purpose of this is to be able to define presheaf models of type theory internal to other presheaf models. These kind of situations actually happen in practice! For example, the model of guarded cubical type theory that combines step-indexing with univalence ought to be an example of this.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To develop this two-fold generalisation of Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting, we resituated the theory in terms of another of Thomas‚Äôs favourite topics: the theory of fibrations, on which Thomas had written the most wonderful lecture notes.
We dedicated our paper to Thomas‚Äôs memory. May he rest in peace.

fr:meta.name: venue

fr:meta.fr:link: LICS ‚Äô25: 40th Annual ACM/IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We study the relationship between partial map classifiers, Sierpi≈Ñski cones, and axioms for synthetic higher categories and domains within univalent foundations. In particular, we show that synthetic ‚àû-categories are closed under partial map classifiers assuming Phoa's principle, and we isolate a new reflective subuniverse of types within which the Sierpi≈Ñski cone (a lax colimit) can be computed as a partial map classifier by strengthening the Segal condition.

The paper currently states that the alternative type theoretic computation of the scone uses the flattening lemma, but this is incorrect. In fact, we need only the fact the dependent sum functor preserves colimits (being left adjoint to base change). This will be corrected in the final version of the paper.

fr:title.text: On Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher universes
Tensorial structure of the lifting doctrine in constructive domain theory

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Tensorial structure of the lifting doctrine in constructive domain theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: Proceedings of Category Theory at Work in Computational Mathematics and Theoretical Informatics

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We present a survey of the two-dimensional and tensorial structure of the lifting doctrine in constructive domain theory, i.e. in the theory of directed-complete partial orders (dcpos) over an arbitrary elementary topos. We establish the universal property of lifting of dcpos as the Sierpi≈Ñski cone, from which we deduce (1) that lifting forms a Kock‚ÄìZ√∂berlein doctrine, (2) that lifting algebras, pointed dcpos, and inductive partial orders form canonically equivalent locally posetal 2-categories, and (3) that the category of lifting algebras is cocomplete, with connected colimits created by the forgetful functor to dcpos. Finally we deduce the symmetric monoidal closure of the Eilenberg‚ÄìMoore resolution of the lifting 2-monad by means of smash products; these are shown to classify both bilinear maps and strict maps, which we prove to coincide in the constructive setting. We provide several concrete computations of the smash product as dcpo coequalisers and lifting algebra coequalisers, and compare these with the more abstract results of Seal. Although all these results are well-known classically, the existing proofs do not apply in a constructive setting; indeed, the classical analysis of the Eilenberg‚ÄìMoore category of the lifting monad relies on the fact that all lifting algebras are free, a condition that is not known to hold constructively.

fr:meta.fr:link: IAS Special Year on Univalent Foundations

fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @book{hottbook, author = {{Univalent Foundations Program}, The}, address = {Institute for Advanced Study}, publisher = {\url{https://homotopytypetheory.org/book}}, year = {2013}, title = {Homotopy Type Theory: Univalent Foundations of Mathematics}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Homotopy type theory is a new branch of mathematics that combines aspects of several different fields in a surprising way. It is based on a recently discovered connection between homotopy theory and type theory. It touches on topics as seemingly distant as the homotopy groups of spheres, the algorithms for type checking, and the definition of weak \infty -groupoids. Homotopy type theory offers a new ‚Äúunivalent‚Äù foundation of mathematics, in which a central role is played by Voevodsky‚Äôs univalence axiom and higher inductive types. The present book is intended as a first systematic exposition of the basics of univalent foundations, and a collection of examples of this new style of reasoning ‚Äî but without requiring the reader to know or learn any formal logic, or to use any computer proof assistant. We believe that univalent foundations will eventually become a viable alternative to set theory as the ‚Äúimplicit foundation‚Äù for the unformalized mathematics done by most mathematicians.

fr:title.text: Forester 5.0 development: canonical URLs, atom feeds, and LSP

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Forester 5.0 development: canonical URLs, atom feeds, and LSP

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Work on Forester 5.0 proceeds apace, generously supported by ARIA who have engaged Kento Okura and myself on a consulting basis to support their internal use of Forester. My recent goals have been to bring Forester closer in line with the architecture of the World Wide Web; to that end, I have made two big improvements.

fr:title.text: First cut at canonical URLs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Trees are addressed by ‚Äúcanonical URLs‚Äù that are meant to be the place where they will ultimately be published. See my blog post on the design for more details. Canonical URLs are of the form https://www.my-host.net/tree-name/; the handling is a little fragile right now and you can expect bugs (but please write to me about them).

fr:title.text: First cut at atom syndication

fr:mainmatter.html:p: It is now possible to syndicate the children of a tree as an Atom feed. This is done currently by including the following directive in the tree you wish to syndicate:

Then, if your tree is located at https://www.my-host.net/tree-name/, you will find that there is an atom feed at https://www.my-host.net/tree-name/atom.xml. There are many subtleties to this, and the atom support will continue to evolve and improve. One thing I need to deal with is the fact that Forester produces nested hyperlinks‚Äîwhich are not valid in HTML! I came up with a pretty slick way to handle this in XSLT, but that Atom renderer is intended to bypass that entirely.

As a side note, I am very happy to see that I am not the only person using the new support for Atom feeds. Patrick‚Äôs fork of Forester is looking pretty cool, and I am excited to learn more from what he is doing. I‚Äôm also relieved that he was able to get rebased atop the ever-changing forester-5.0-dev branch.

fr:title.text: Federation is still janky

fr:mainmatter.html:p: One thing I want to start designing soon is how best to handle federated forests. Right now, Forester bundles all the imported material under a foreign/my-friends-host/ directory and routes all links accordingly, but in many (but not all!) cases one would want to not bundle things at all and instead have links routed directly to the canonical URLs as published on the World Wide Web. I am not sure of the best design for this, so I welcome feedback. In the meanwhile, enjoy the janky prototype feel.

fr:title.text: Language server; code completion via effects and handlers

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Language server; code completion via effects and handlers

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Kento is hard at work hardening Forester‚Äôs language server. I am hoping that we will have something to show on the scale of a week.

There were some subtleties about how to provide completion information at a source location‚Äîwhich is at least as complex as the expander itself, since scope emerges from the expansion process. We had something fairly broken in place, which I have spent Thursday and Friday morning replacing with something cool using OCaml 5‚Äôs effects and handlers. The idea is to instrument the expander with an effect that notifies observes that it has entered a source range; this can be handled as a no-op, or by querying the scope‚Äôs available symbols when it enters the desired range and throwing away the continuation, and resuming the continuation otherwise to keep searching. This approach allows all the scope-handling code to be unified into a single routine, whose behaviour is controlled by effect handlers on the outside.

As a side note, I am looking forward to when the next version of Topiary is released, which should contain support for formatting OCaml‚Äôs effect handlers. Right now we don‚Äôt use the nice notation because we are stuck on Topiary 0.6.0.

fr:title.text: Project Pterosaur: yes, I‚Äôm building a new proof assistant

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Project Pterosaur: yes, I‚Äôm building a new proof assistant

fr:mainmatter.html:p: I swore after building cooltt, redtt, and RedPRL that I would never build another proof assistant, as the experience burned around four years of my PhD and resulted (at least directly) in very little publishable work‚Äîbut, to be fair, I probably would not have made the key mathematical discovery of my PhD thesis if it were not for these engineering experiments. But I‚Äôm back on my bullshit, as the young people say, and hard at work building a new interactive proof assistant that I have code-named Project Pterosaur.

fr:title.text: Locales in dependent type theory?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The goal of Pterosaur is to explore the adaptation of locales from Isabelle to dependent type theory, as a lightweight but extremely expressive alternative to type classes. My colleague Larry Paulson has written some great blog posts about locales in Isabelle, and I strongly recommend reading Ballarin‚Äôs Exploring the Structure of an Algebra Text with Locales to get a feel for what is possible. Here is what locales do:

html:ol.html:li: Locales appear to completely solve the pain involved when building up hierarchies of mathematical structures and notations, allowing you to effortlessly combine theories along a common core (e.g. defining rings in terms of a multiplicative monoid and an Abelian group sharing the same carrier).

Locales allow you to add new methods to a theory after the fact, and they will magically be available on anything that extended that theory. You can also add new links in the theory graph, and both cycles and diamonds are allowed so long as they are coherent; this is useful if you want to silently regard (e.g.) the space of endomaps¬†on a set as a monoid, etc.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In comparison to modules and type classes, the strength of locales is that you don‚Äôt have to decide ahead of time whether you want to ‚Äúbundle‚Äù fields with their carriers, etc. In contrast, a great deal of the difficult work of mathematical library design and maintainance in tools like Rocq, Agda, and Lean is figuring out just what things to bundle, and fixing things when your choices inevitably lead to breakage, etc. Locales avoid these problems entirely.

Finally, a reasonably usable locale implementation can be obtained without any higher-order unification whatsoever. I have a feeling that will be extremely important, given how unreliable (and incorrect!) most implementations of higher-order unification are; the situation is so bad that it is actually an open problem to define a correct higher-order unification algorithm in the presence of singleton types (such as the unit type). I do think that this can be solved (and may have already been solved by Andras Kovacs), but my point is that the prognosis for unification in dependent type theory is bad.

fr:title.text: Experimental implementation in Lean

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The other interesting thing about Pterosaur is that I am implementing it in Lean; I am not verifying anything, and am making free use of Lean‚Äôs partial keyword (which hides potentially divergent code from definitional equality). Instead, I am thinking of Lean as a ‚Äúbetter OCaml‚Äù: I can‚Äôt speak to the quality of the compiler and code generator, but I can absolutely say that from the perspective of day-to-day programming, Lean has a lot of affordances that make it extremely nice to use. On the other hand, Lean‚Äôs story for modularity is not so good; but I hope they don‚Äôt ‚Äúfix‚Äù it any time soon, because I think that something like locales could be a good option for Lean itself in the future if I am able to demonstrate their potential in the context of Pterosaur‚Äôs clean-room implementation.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To develop this two-fold generalisation of Hofmann‚ÄìStreicher lifting, we resituated the theory in terms of another of Thomas‚Äôs favourite topics: the theory of fibrations, on which Thomas had written the most wonderful lecture notes.
We dedicated our paper to Thomas‚Äôs memory. May he rest in peace.
